by Timothy McNamara
Lou Giangiulio and Robert
Montgomery, who topped a field
of seven presidential candidates in
last Tuesday's elections for the
officers and representatives of the
Class of 1990, will go head to
head in the October 28 run-offs.
In the vice-presidential race, Jon
Jacobson and James Rosen each
captured about a quarter of the
458 votes cast, also forcing a
run-off.
Outright winners included
Cathy Kadets, who received 51.5%
of the vote for secretary, and
Jenifer Willann, who defeated
Alistair Phillips by 39 votes in the
race for treasurer.
George Lerner, Darryl Flaherty, Laura Smith, Susan Fox, and
Audrey Gedachian also won
places on next Tuesday's run-off
ballot in the contest for class
representative. The three top
vote-getters will assume seats on
the Student Council.
"My intentions are sincere and
I'm confident I can fulfill every
aspect and duty of this position,"
commented Giangiulio in a preelection statement. The economics major, who led the pack of
presidential candidates with 186
of the 500 votes cast, emphasized his involvement in the Hopkins
community at the October 16
Candidates' Forum.
"I am always available," he
declared. Citing his roles as a prefrosh coordinator, a BI A
representative, a dorm social
committee member and a position
on the wrestling team, he added,
"I am visible around campus."
Remarking that the function of
Student Council is "to improve
student life," he added that "the
best class is an informed class."

Fall Jazz Festival
Begins Tradition
by Lisa Weisbord
Could the Jazz Festival eventually become the Fall's
equivalent to Spring Fair? Student
Council president Mark Komisky
hopes that this year's Jazz
Festival "has set a precedent and
will become a tradition here at
Hopkins."
Komisky stated that "Spring
Fair started in a way similar to
last Saturday's Jazz Festival."
Originally, Spring Fair was held
on one quad and over the years
it has expanded and taken over
the entire campus. Komisky feels
that as time goes on and interest
increases the Jazz Festival can
also be expanded.
Senior Scott Seidman, who
planned and ran last weekend's
event, would also "like to continue on a much bigger scale."

He would like to search for sponsorship and feels that "if the
budget comes from elsewhere
something as big as Spring Fair
may be feasible in the future."
From noon to 5 p.m. the music
of "Exit 17", "The Tangled
Hangers," and "Moon August"
filled Gilman Quad. According to
Seidman, "by the end of the
Festival when "Moon August,"
a popular Baltimore group came
on, there were probably 80 people there."
In addition to postering
Homewood "over and over
again," according to Seidman,
"Loyola, Notre Dame, Peabody,
Goucher, and The Maryland Institute of Art also were
postered." Komisky added "that
the poor turnout was a result of
a general lack of knowledge com'bined with the cold weather."

Baltimore Honors
Wolman's Career
by Tom McNamara
On Thursday, October 16,
1986, Baltimore's Municipal
Building was rededicated as the
Abel Wolman Municipal Building
in a ceremony held in front of the
building at 200 North Holiday
Street.
Wolman's 71-year career as
"an engineer, consultant,
educator and writer," according
to the program for the event, has
resulted in "accomplishments in
engineering and public health"
which "have made Baltimore
world famous. His most important contribution, the standardized chlorination of water, was accomplished at the Montebello
Filtration Plant. This revolutionary treatment of drinking
water has been cited as the single
most important factor in controling waterborne diseases, saving
countless lives on every continent."
The speakers at the program,
including Mayor Schaefer and
Francis Kuchta, Director of the
Baltimore City Department of
Public Works, praised this and
other accomplishments, including

Wolman's foresight in planning
of water supplies for Baltimore in
the future.
Schaefer said that the way the
idea for the rededication of the
building came about was that
Kuchta "came into my office one
day and said, 'There is a great
man in the city of Baltimore who
we should honor.— Schaefer asked him,"What do you want to do
for Dr. Wolman?"
When Wolman himself spoke,
he said that he could not claim all
the credit for the things that the
other speakers had praised, and
expressed the hope that there
would be a plaque in the building
honoring the "thousands of
others" who have worked on projects with which he has been involved. Referring to the sweeping statements made about his
career by the others, he recounted
the story of a man whose name
was "going to go down in
history, if not sooner."
In the concluding remarks for
the ceremony, Dr. F. Pierce
Linaweaver said of Wolman,
"His services will always be in
great demand."

Centennial with Symposium
by Gregory Francis
In a grand effort to promote "a
mixed community of critical
schools which can coexist,"
Richard Macksey, professor of
Comparative Literature at the
Humanities Center is this week
organizing the centennial anniversary of the literary journal,
Modern Language Notes. The
commemoration will be at Hopkins and will take the form of a
two-day symposium on October
24 and 25.
The symposium-celebration
will feature representatives of
North America's greatest institutions of learning: Hopkins, Harvard, Yale, Cornell, Chicago,
Duke, and the University of
Montreal.
Established in 1886, Modern
Language Notes was among the

first American literary journals of
its kind. Going to press five times
per year, the journal has the purpose to represent the major
modern languages; and, according to Macksey, the journal
"was but one enduring manifestation of President Gilman's program to translate the European
higher learning to this country
and its own historical aspirations."
As concerns the delegations,
Macksey declared, "I hope there
will be some discussion across
disciplinary lines." Similar conferences have been known to have
shown a lack of "transdisciplinary dialogue," a difficulty the
professor intends to avoid. To
mete out this end, both Macksey
and the former general editor of
MLN,Paul R. Olson have arranged as comfortable a stay as is

possible for the visitors.
Hopkins can expect many lectures on subjects such as "Critical
Self-Consciousness or: Dennis
Martiniz and the Uses of
Theory" from Professor Stanley
Fish of Duke University, and
"Criticism as Institutions: 100
German Studies in MLN" from
Hopkins' native son Dr. William
McClain of the German Department.
The public, particularly
Hopkins students, are invited to
benefit from this assembly as the
majority of lectures will be held
in Mudd Hall.
Besides the very weighty
undertones in the nature of the
symposium, it is refreshing to
note Macksey's first aspiration
for the affair: "I hope it'll be a
nice birthday party."

A Shocking Day
Yesterday was a shocking day for the
Homewood campus indeed. In an unexpected move, George Fisher, dean of the
School of Arts and Sciences and Matthew
Crenson, associate dean of Arts and
Sciences, suddenly announced their plans
to resign from the administration at the end
of this academic year.
The two deans apparently made their
decision to resign in order to return to
teaching and research, in good Hopkins
form.
The resignation of any dean is certainly
grounds for some interest and concern. But
the simultaneous resignation fo Fisher and
Crenson is, without a doubt, one of the
most important administrative changes to
occur at Homewood in recent years.
As the top men in the School of Arts and
Sciences (the largest academic division at
Homewood), Fisher and Crenson have
done an excellent job in directing and coordinating a vast array of academic departments. Furthermore, both deans have been
remarkably accessible and eager to work
with students.
It's difficult to single out any specific
achievement exclusively attributable to the
work of the departing deans. However, that
probably is as it should be. After all, the
mark of many good and efficient administrators is the lack of a distinctive

mark.
As the shock of the resignations abates,
thoughts must turn to the future of the
School of Arts and Sciences. Soon a search
will be underway to find a successor to
Fisher. The administration should keep two
things in mind as it begins looking for a new
dean.
First, students ought to be given a voice
in the selection process. No dean has a
more profound and lasting effect on the
academic prestige of the University than the
dean of the School of Arts and Sciences.
His decisions directly affect students and
what they study. It seems appropriate,
therefore, that students should be given
some input in the selection of such a new
dean.
Second, the selection process ought to be
targetted to an individual who will be willing to devote many years to the Homewood
administration. Developing the necessary
contacts and inside working knowledge of
an institution as complicated as Hopkins
takes years. It's a long-term
commitment—not the kind of job that
should be tracked for a rapid turn-over.
Fisher and Crenson will certainly and
rightfully be missed in the Homewood administration next year. We only hope that
a prudent selection process will result in the
hiring of equally competent successors.

At the Bottom of the Pack
Two weeks ago, an Ad Hoc Faculty
Planning Committee issued a long-awaited
report on the status of the M.S.E. Library.
The report, which was eighteen months in
the making, concluded that the library
"faces serious problems within its collections, a shortage of personnel—particularly
bibliographers—and pressing short-term
and long-term space requirements." Even
an eighteen minute walk through M.S.E.
dramatically confirms those conclusions.
For the very few among us who haven't
had the occasion to visit the library recently, two observations are striking. First, the
stacks are jammed full. There is often so
little room on a shelf that stackers resort
to cramming books into little crevices on
top of other books. Second, the books that
are available (with the exception of scientific texts) are often hopelessly out of date.
You may be able to find an eighteenth century printing of Moliere, but good luck
searching for something as 'exotic' as
Vonnegut.
These two observations point to two of
the most serious problems addressed in the
Faculty Planning Committee's report—
namely the shortage of space and the
miserable acquisition track-record of
M.S.E.
Currently, the library is full and has
essentially been so since the mid 1970's.
Overflow, until now, has been managed by
moving books into the Gilman stacks for
storage. But within two or three years, even
that overflow space will be exhaused and
possibly reduced in size due to upcoming
renovations to Gilman. Eventually, plans
call for converting Rowland Hall into additional stack space. But even liberal
estimates suggest that such a change
couldn't be finished at least until the early
or mid 1990's.

These space limitations put the library in
a difficult position to be sure. But what is
astonishing is the failure of the University
historically to do anything to correct the
problem.
New books are, of course, the second
major problem addressed by the Faculty
Planning Committee's report. According to
the report, among fourteen comparable
libraries which belong to the Association
of Research Libraries, Hopkins ranks thirteenth in the acquisition rate of new books.
Among the 106 member ARL libraries,
Hopkins ranks 101. Any way you slice it,
the M.S.E. Library comes out at the very
bottom of the pack.
Undoubtedly, part of the reason for
Hopkins' shortcomings in acquisitions is the
fact that there will soon be nowhere to put
additional titles. Nevertheless, Hopkins'
miserable acquisition rate cannot be simply glossed over. Already, some departments
have indicated that their programs are suffering from a lack of literary resources. If
those claims are true, and they probably
are, the University should be outraged.
No top-rated prestigious research institution can function without a top-rated
prestigious library. If Hopkins is indeed
dedicated to the acquisition and disemination of knowledge, it needs to make a much
stronger commitment to the improvement
of the M.S.E. Library. Specifically, more
space needs to be built, more books need

pp. 81-102), Dr. Robert Thatcher

Maryland and Dr. Diane Fishbein
of The Department of Criminal

electrophysiology to study some

mean lead burden (as measured in
hair) and low I.Q.. That is, the
lowest achievers had the highest
lead burden.

malnourished, and who lived in
high traffic zones with much lead

pollution are the most at risk for
poor job performance and crimininality.. If blacks fit into this
category they are the victims of
our environment and society. One
cannot infer from the work of
Gordon and Gottfredson any
deeper significance about blacks
as a group. The danger of uncritical interpretation of the work
of Gordon and Gottfredson is that
it can so easily be twisted to
satisfy a bigoted and racist point
of view.
Ruth Aranow

Roger's Version

Approach John Updike's latest
novel, Roger's Version, \kith a
slide rule and a Latin dictionary.
Both are necessary as Updike
proves that more research is not
necessarily better. This is not to
imply that his story is in any way
lacking, or that the points which
he makes about faith and middle
age are insubstantial. There is a
very solid novel hiding under the
technological and theological
trappings.
The Roger of the title is a professor of theology at a prestigious
New England liberal arts college
(read Harvard). He has had a difficult past, changing marriages
and leaving the active ministry,
but now has easily settled into
academic life. He has the requisite book-lined office and
tweed jacket, as well as the usual
large house and bored wife. He
drives an Audi and smokes a
pipe. The image is familiar and
comfortable.
An unsettling force is introduced when Dale Kohler, a graduate
student in computer science,
comes to Roger about a grant for
a project. Dale intends to prove
by mathematical manipulation

that God exists. Roger is nonplussed and becomes more so as
Dale goes on at length about the
mathematical improbability of the
Universe,
i.e. ". . . the
background microwave radiation
of 3 K discovered in 1964 has
been observed to be constant to
one part in ten thousand . . ."or
". . . take a neutron: if it were only point nine nine eight of its actual value, free protons would
decay into neutrons via positron
emission and there would be no
atoms at all!" This is all very interesting, but not half so as the
student's parting shot that an errant niece of the professor's has
moved into the area. This sets
Roger off on a mission to help the
girl find a job and a safer place
to live—he finds her in a public
housing project. In the meantime,
he becomes attracted to her and
carries on (largely in his own
mind) and affair with her. This
nicely counterbalancees his suspicion that his wife has taken up
with Dale, whom he initially
hired as a math tutor for his son.
Above the more carnal action,
Roger and Dale carry on a
number of conversations about
the nature of God and the lack of
proof inherent in faith. At the
book's beginning, Dale's faith is
unshakeable, fundamental. The
course of the book charts the
decline of his basic faith while at

the same time pointing up the
durability of Roger's more worldworn beliefs.
These elements are liberally interspersed with lengthy passages
about particle physics and the
theology of Tertullian. While
these sections certainly add versimilitude, they do little for the
reader who is unfamiliar with
Heisenberg or De Carnis. As for
suggesting the intrusion of
technology into faith, these
passages may be useful but are
ultimately more distracting.
The other obvious weak point
which turns out to be useful is
Roger's role as narrator. Because
the entire novel is seen through
Roger's eyes, all the action is at
the same time distorted and instructive. Roger's true feelings
toward the emptiness of his marriage are revealed in his descriptions of his wife's meetings with
Dale. In the same way, his reaction to his niece reinforced earlier
comments about the family problems of his youth, which she
personified.
If faith and technology are to
coexist, there must be a boundary
between them. This is the final
message in Dale's quest for God.
In wanting to know too much, he
ends up believing nothing. Roger
finds that there is serenity in his
less technological faith, and in the
end, both have grown.

24 and 25.

North America's greatest institutions of learning: Hopkins, Harvard, Yale, Cornell, Chicago,

Montreal.

Language Notes was among the

first American literary journals of
its kind. Going to press five times
per year, the journal has the purpose to represent the major
modern languages; and, according to Macksey, the journal
"was but one enduring manifestation of President Gilman's program to translate the European
higher learning to this country
and its own historical aspirations."
As concerns the delegations,
Macksey declared, "I hope there
will be some discussion across
disciplinary lines." Similar conferences have been known to have
shown a lack of "transdisciplinary dialogue," a difficulty the
professor intends to avoid. To
mete out this end, both Macksey
and the former general editor of
MLN,Paul R. Olson have arranged as comfortable a stay as is

possible for the visitors.

Self-Consciousness or: Dennis
Martiniz and the Uses of
Theory" from Professor Stanley
Fish of Duke University, and
"Criticism as Institutions: 100
German Studies in MLN" from
Hopkins' native son Dr. William
McClain of the German Department.
The public, particularly
Hopkins students, are invited to
benefit from this assembly as the
majority of lectures will be held
in Mudd Hall.

undertones in the nature of the
symposium, it is refreshing to
note Macksey's first aspiration
for the affair: "I hope it'll be a
nice birthday party."

A Shocking Day
Yesterday was a shocking day for the
Homewood campus indeed. In an unexpected move, George Fisher, dean of the
School of Arts and Sciences and Matthew
Crenson, associate dean of Arts and
Sciences, suddenly announced their plans
to resign from the administration at the end
of this academic year.
The two deans apparently made their
decision to resign in order to return to
teaching and research, in good Hopkins
form.
The resignation of any dean is certainly
grounds for some interest and concern. But
the simultaneous resignation fo Fisher and
Crenson is, without a doubt, one of the
most important administrative changes to
occur at Homewood in recent years.
As the top men in the School of Arts and
Sciences (the largest academic division at
Homewood), Fisher and Crenson have
done an excellent job in directing and coordinating a vast array of academic departments. Furthermore, both deans have been
remarkably accessible and eager to work
with students.
It's difficult to single out any specific
achievement exclusively attributable to the
work of the departing deans. However, that
probably is as it should be. After all, the
mark of many good and efficient administrators is the lack of a distinctive

mark.
As the shock of the resignations abates,
thoughts must turn to the future of the
School of Arts and Sciences. Soon a search
will be underway to find a successor to
Fisher. The administration should keep two
things in mind as it begins looking for a new
dean.
First, students ought to be given a voice
in the selection process. No dean has a
more profound and lasting effect on the
academic prestige of the University than the
dean of the School of Arts and Sciences.
His decisions directly affect students and
what they study. It seems appropriate,
therefore, that students should be given
some input in the selection of such a new
dean.
Second, the selection process ought to be
targetted to an individual who will be willing to devote many years to the Homewood
administration. Developing the necessary
contacts and inside working knowledge of
an institution as complicated as Hopkins
takes years. It's a long-term
commitment—not the kind of job that
should be tracked for a rapid turn-over.
Fisher and Crenson will certainly and
rightfully be missed in the Homewood administration next year. We only hope that
a prudent selection process will result in the
hiring of equally competent successors.

At the Bottom of the Pack
Two weeks ago, an Ad Hoc Faculty
Planning Committee issued a long-awaited
report on the status of the M.S.E. Library.
The report, which was eighteen months in
the making, concluded that the library
"faces serious problems within its collections, a shortage of personnel—particularly
bibliographers—and pressing short-term
and long-term space requirements." Even
an eighteen minute walk through M.S.E.
dramatically confirms those conclusions.
For the very few among us who haven't
had the occasion to visit the library recently, two observations are striking. First, the
stacks are jammed full. There is often so
little room on a shelf that stackers resort
to cramming books into little crevices on
top of other books. Second, the books that
are available (with the exception of scientific texts) are often hopelessly out of date.
You may be able to find an eighteenth century printing of Moliere, but good luck
searching for something as 'exotic' as
Vonnegut.
These two observations point to two of
the most serious problems addressed in the
Faculty Planning Committee's report—
namely the shortage of space and the
miserable acquisition track-record of
M.S.E.
Currently, the library is full and has
essentially been so since the mid 1970's.
Overflow, until now, has been managed by
moving books into the Gilman stacks for
storage. But within two or three years, even
that overflow space will be exhaused and
possibly reduced in size due to upcoming
renovations to Gilman. Eventually, plans
call for converting Rowland Hall into additional stack space. But even liberal
estimates suggest that such a change
couldn't be finished at least until the early
or mid 1990's.

These space limitations put the library in
a difficult position to be sure. But what is
astonishing is the failure of the University
historically to do anything to correct the
problem.
New books are, of course, the second
major problem addressed by the Faculty
Planning Committee's report. According to
the report, among fourteen comparable
libraries which belong to the Association
of Research Libraries, Hopkins ranks thirteenth in the acquisition rate of new books.
Among the 106 member ARL libraries,
Hopkins ranks 101. Any way you slice it,
the M.S.E. Library comes out at the very
bottom of the pack.
Undoubtedly, part of the reason for
Hopkins' shortcomings in acquisitions is the
fact that there will soon be nowhere to put
additional titles. Nevertheless, Hopkins'
miserable acquisition rate cannot be simply glossed over. Already, some departments
have indicated that their programs are suffering from a lack of literary resources. If
those claims are true, and they probably
are, the University should be outraged.
No top-rated prestigious research institution can function without a top-rated
prestigious library. If Hopkins is indeed
dedicated to the acquisition and disemination of knowledge, it needs to make a much
stronger commitment to the improvement
of the M.S.E. Library. Specifically, more
space needs to be built, more books need
to be bought, and more bibliographers need
to be hired.
None of these suggestions is easy and all
are expensive. But if Hopkins intends to retain its reputation of academic excellence,
it needs to devote inordinate resources and
attention to the M.S.E. Library during the
next few years.

academic life. He has the requisite book-lined office and
tweed jacket, as well as the usual
large house and bored wife. He
drives an Audi and smokes a
pipe. The image is familiar and
comfortable.
An unsettling force is introduced when Dale Kohler, a graduate
student in computer science,
comes to Roger about a grant for
a project. Dale intends to prove
by mathematical manipulation

that God exists. Roger is nonplussed and becomes more so as
Dale goes on at length about the
mathematical improbability of the
Universe,
i.e. ". . . the
background microwave radiation
of 3 K discovered in 1964 has
been observed to be constant to
one part in ten thousand . . ."or
". . . take a neutron: if it were only point nine nine eight of its actual value, free protons would
decay into neutrons via positron
emission and there would be no
atoms at all!" This is all very interesting, but not half so as the
student's parting shot that an errant niece of the professor's has
moved into the area. This sets
Roger off on a mission to help the
girl find a job and a safer place
to live—he finds her in a public
housing project. In the meantime,
he becomes attracted to her and
carries on (largely in his own
mind) and affair with her. This
nicely counterbalancees his suspicion that his wife has taken up
with Dale, whom he initially
hired as a math tutor for his son.
Above the more carnal action,
Roger and Dale carry on a
number of conversations about
the nature of God and the lack of
proof inherent in faith. At the
book's beginning, Dale's faith is
unshakeable, fundamental. The
course of the book charts the
decline of his basic faith while at

the same time pointing up the
durability of Roger's more worldworn beliefs.
These elements are liberally interspersed with lengthy passages
about particle physics and the
theology of Tertullian. While
these sections certainly add versimilitude, they do little for the
reader who is unfamiliar with
Heisenberg or De Carnis. As for
suggesting the intrusion of
technology into faith, these
passages may be useful but are
ultimately more distracting.
The other obvious weak point
which turns out to be useful is
Roger's role as narrator. Because
the entire novel is seen through
Roger's eyes, all the action is at
the same time distorted and instructive. Roger's true feelings
toward the emptiness of his marriage are revealed in his descriptions of his wife's meetings with
Dale. In the same way, his reaction to his niece reinforced earlier
comments about the family problems of his youth, which she
personified.
If faith and technology are to
coexist, there must be a boundary
between them. This is the final
message in Dale's quest for God.
In wanting to know too much, he
ends up believing nothing. Roger
finds that there is serenity in his
less technological faith, and in the
end, both have grown.
